title: Questor share tips: Hold RELX as results on target
text:
1,155.00 +2.00 
The information group has built a strong position providing technical data to lawyers, acountants and scientists, says Questor 
RELX (Stuttgart: RDEB.SG - news ) £11.57 +4p Questor says HOLD 
RELX [LON:REL] , the owner of Lexis Nexis and The Lancet reference services, said yesterday it was on target to hit full-year targets. 
Questor thinks the steady (if somewhat boring) performance is just what makes the shares attractive to long-term investors. 
The Anglo-Dutch group, formerly known as FTSE 100-listed media group Reed Elsevier (Amsterdam: REN.AS - news ) , is currently navigating a successful shift from print to digital. 
The company historically provided reference material for lawyers, accountants and scientists in print. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) now offers all this material online and digitally through a service called Lexis Nexis. 
Law firms and accountancies pay subscription fees so that their staff can access the latest information. 
In the medical world the company owns well known reference brands such as Grey’s Anatomy and medical journal The Lancet. 
RELX (LSE: REL.L - news ) has a small army of specialists collecting data and then creating easily-searchable databases. 
The business has been a steady performer this year. Group revenue has increased 3pc in the nine months to the end of September. 
The company’s risk and business information division showed the fastest growth, with revenue up 7pc, while the legal division was slower with 1pc revenue growth, and the science, technical and medical division increased revenue by 2pc. 
RELX is forecast to generate £1.7bn in pre-tax profits, giving 61p in earnings per share, from £6.1bn of revenue in the year to the end of December. 
The profit margin of about 30pc should be defendable as it is difficult for competitors to replicate the army of researchers who have the technical knowledge required. 
The company also generates plenty of cash, which covers the dividend payments more than twice. The shares are expected to pay a 28.9p dividend this year, offering a prospective yield of 2.5pc. The payout is set to increase by 6pc a year. 
The company isn’t risk-free as the accounting and law industries are always exposed to economic downturns, when layoffs will reduce the number of subscriptions required for the LexisNexis service. The shares suffered a five-year slump after the 2008 credit crisis, when profits halved. 
The shares also command a premium to the wider market, trading on 19 times forecast earnings, falling to 17 times next year. However, this remains one to hold for the long term.
